awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Toward Predictive Models for Diagnosis & Severity Assessment of Heart Disease from Diverse Temporal Data
awd_abstract_narration:
The project aims to lay the foundation for developing computational methods for improved diagnosis and prediction of heart disease from noisy data gathered from patients. The data comprises both time-series signals and images gathered from patients suffering from Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM), the most common cardiac genetic disease. Current diagnosis limitations lead to undetected cases that may result in sudden cardiac death, often in active young individuals. The project focuses on advancing the computational means for utilizing data that is relatively fast and low-cost to obtain but is hard to interpret, namely sonogram images (Echo) and electrocardiogram time-series (ECG). Developing tools that improve diagnosis and prediction while making the basis for such tools simpler and less-expensive stands to benefit large populations, especially in under-privileged areas where state-of-the-art imaging technology is scarce.

This project develops probabilistic, supervised and unsupervised machine learning methods and tools. Specifically, it extends the framework of hidden Markov model to support effective use of 12-lead ECG as well as integration of Echo image data. These information sources are relatively inexpensive and nonintrusive but have hitherto been under-utilized in computer-assisted HCM-detection. Developing the proposed models and methods provides a unique training opportunity for young scientists, by conducting inter-disciplinary research while utilizing diverse types of data. The research also paves the road toward introducing probabilistic integrative methods in other disease-domains, as well as in other data-intensive applications outside medicine.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to lay the foundations for developing computational methods for improved diagnosis and prediction of disease from noisy data gathered from patients, with a focus on heart disease. Specific objectives included gathering a variety of patient data and converting it to a form amenable to computation, as well as developing computational tools for analyzing and using such data toward disease diagnosis and prediction.

Throughout the project new data was gathered, including time-series signals, images and information from the Electronic Health Record (EHR) of hundreds of patients suffering from Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM) -- the most common cardiac genetic disease. Current diagnosis methods of this condition suffer limitations that lead to undetected cases. Cases that are left undiagnosed and untreated may result in sudden cardiac death, often in active young individuals.

The project focused on advancing machine learning and other computational means that utilize data about HCM patients to improve physicians' ability to distinguish high-risk from non-high-risk patients.  Developing such computational methods is particularly challenging due to a situation known as data imbalance. That is, the fact that the vast majority of the population is not at-risk while only a small fraction is high-risk, leading to vast amounts of data pertaining to not-at-risk populations while only scant information is available concerning high-risk populations. Data imbalance makes it difficult to derive characteristic patterns and to devise effective diagnostic and treatment plans for high-risk patients.

We have developed strategies based on statistical machine learning and include a combination of feature selection, sampling methods and hierarchical classification that directly address this data imbalance. These have proven effective in identifying high-risk patients in several contexts, including chronic kidney disease (where data  from thousands of patients was examined) and heart disease (where data from hundreds of patients was utilized), including ventricular arrhythmias and atrial fibrillation. Moreover, the method developed can identify a relatively small number of indicators that are recorded in the electronic health records -- some of which were hitherto not used for diagnosis -- which can serve to effectively identify and stratify the risk level of individual patients.

Another important aspect of severe disease, such as heart or kidney disease, is the presence of multiple co-occurring adverse health conditions, which contribute to poor prognosis and increased hospitalization. Such adverse health conditions are typically associated with the health record of the patient through standardized condition-codes. By  employing machine learning and topic modeling to the condition-codes occurring in electronic health records, we have devised a method for identifying patterns of co-occurring conditions that characterize different cohorts of patients.

Overall, the work accomplished throughout the project period has exceeded the goals we had set, as it has gone beyond the planned preparatory work while actually leading to the development of possible computational solutions. The introduced methods will be further advanced in future work to support physicians throughout the process of diagnosis and treatment planning for patients suffering from complicated adverse conditions.
